importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date on which former French President Nicolas Sarkozy began serving his five-year prison sentence, marking a historic moment in French political history.
The day of his imprisonment signals a significant event in democratic accountability, as it is the first time a former head of state in the EU has been incarcerated.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Sarkozy began his five-year jail term on this date, setting a precedent for legal accountability among former political leaders.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France, began serving a five-year jail sentence on 2025-10-21, making him the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned.
The conviction stems from criminal conspiracy related to accepting illegal payments from Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 election campaign.
Sarkozy has consistently denied the charges, and his lawyers filed an immediate appeal for release.
He will be held in solitary confinement in a 9-square-meter cell at La Sante prison, with one daily walk and three weekly visits.
The presiding judge, Nathalie Gavarino, described the offenses as of 'exceptional gravity' and ordered imprisonment regardless of appeal.
The court has two months to review the release appeal filed by Sarkozyâ€™s legal team.
Sarkozy is the first French leader to be imprisoned since Philippe Petain, a WWII collaborationist.
He plans to bring a biography of Jesus and a copy of The Count of Monte Cristo to prison, referencing themes of innocence and justice.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy began a five-year prison sentence on 2025-10-21 at La Sante prison in Paris, becoming the first former head of a European Union state to be jailed. The conviction, stemming from criminal conspiracy involving illegal payments from Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 election campaign, is described as of 'exceptional gravity' by presiding judge Nathalie Gavarino. Sarkozy has consistently denied the charges and has filed an appeal for release, with the court having two months to review it. He will be held in solitary confinement with limited contact, and his case marks a historic moment in French political history, as he is the first French leader to be imprisoned since WWII collaborator Philippe Petain. The event has sparked public outcry, with supporters rallying outside his home, and Sarkozy expressing his belief in truth and innocence through statements and references to literary themes of justice.
title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy starts five-year jail term
